en_first_half: When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast, he went out for a stroll on the beach. The little narrow, crooked town of Dover hid itself away from the beach, and ran its head into the chalk cliffs, like a marine ostrich. The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling wildly about, and the sea did what it liked, and what it liked was destruction. It thundered at the town, and thundered at the cliffs, and brought the coast down, madly. The air among the
en_second_half: houses was of so strong a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be dipped in it, as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea. A little fishing was done in the port, and a quantity of strolling about by night, and looking seaward: particularly at those times when the tide made, and was near flood. Small tradesmen, who did no business whatever, sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes, and it was remarkable that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter.
en_results: aps of stones was thick with the smell of salt and seaweed, and the cries of the gulls wheeling overhead. Mr. Lorry walked along the beach, his feet sinking into the wet sand, his eyes fixed on the turmoil of the sea. He felt small and insignificant in the face of such power, and yet, at the same time, he felt a sense of awe and wonder at the sheer force of nature. As he walked,

The sun was hidden behind a veil of grey cloud, and the wind whipped the waves into a frenzy, sending spray flying high into the air. Mr. Lorry walked along the beach, his feet sinking into the wet sand, his eyes fixed on the turmoil of the sea. He felt small and insignificant in the face of such power, and yet, at the same time, he felt a sense of awe and wonder at the sheer force of nature. As he walked, he stumbled upon a piece of driftwood, worn smooth by the constant pounding of the waves. He picked it up, feeling the rough texture of the wood beneath his fingers, and began to walk again, lost in thought. The sound of the sea was like music to his ears, a constant ebb and flow that seemed to match the rhythm of his own heartbeat. He walked for a long time, the only sound the crashing of the waves and the cries of the gulls, until he came to a place where the cliffs fell away, and the beach opened out into a small cove. In the centre of the cove was a small boat, pulled up onto the sand, its sails torn and its hull battered. Mr. Lorry felt a pang of curiosity, and walked towards the boat, wondering what story it might tell of the sea and its fury.

es_first_half: Terminado el almuerzo, el señor Lorry salió a dar un paseíto por la playa. No se divisaba desde ella la pequeña e irregular ciudad de Dover, excepción hecha de sus tejados que, metidos entre picachos de canteras calizas, semejaban gigantesca ostra marina. Era la playa un desierto erizado de peñascales y plagado de escollos, donde la mar hacía lo que se la antojaba, y lo que se la antojaba invariablemente era destruir. Casi de continuo rugía contra la ciudad, bramaba contra los farallones, embestía contra los peñascos que pretendían oponerse a su paso y los derribaba con estruendo. Respirábase en las casas un olor tan fuerte a pescado, que no parecía sino que los
es_second_half: habitantes de las aguas salían de éstas para curar en las casas sus enfermedades, de la misma manera que las personas enfermas suelen buscar la salud en los baños de mar. Algunos, muy pocos, se dedicaban a la pesca en aquellas aguas, y si durante el día la playa estaba siempre desierta, en cambio por la noche se veían personas que clavaban sus miradas inquietas en la inmensidad del mar. Comerciantes insignificantes a los que nunca se veía hacer un negocio, realizaban de pronto fortunas inmensas que no tenían explicación racional, y era muy de notar que nadie, por aquellos lugares, podía sufrir la presencia de una luz, de la que huían como del demonio.

El señor Lorry, que había salido a gozar del paseíto, no podía menos de sentir cierta tristeza al ver la lucha incesante de la mar contra la tierra. Parecíale que aquella era una metáfora de la vida misma, en la que las fuerzas de la naturaleza se enfrentaban a la debilidad humana. Mientras caminaba, notó que la playa estaba llena de restos de naufragios, recordatorios de la furia de la mar. Mientras caminaba, notó que la playa estaba llena de restos de naufragios, recordatorios de la furia de la mar. Se detuvo a examinar uno de ellos, un trozo de madera astillada, y se preguntó cuántas historias de dolor y de muerte se escondían detrás de aquella simple pieza de madera. La mar, que parecía tener un lenguaje propio, le hablaba de la fugasidad de la vida y de la impotencia humana ante la fuerza de la naturaleza. El señor Lorry se sintió pequeño y solo en medio de la inmensidad del oceáno, pero al mismo tiempo, se sintió conectado a algo más grande que él mismo, algo que lo trascendía. La mar, con su eterna lucha contra la tierra, le recordó que la vida es un ciclo de destrucción y creación, y que la belleza y la tristeza están inextricablemente unidas. El señor Lorry continuó su paseíto, pero ya no estaba solo, porque la mar le había hablado y él había escuchado.

en_first_half: Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop behind the counter as he came in. Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age, with a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything, a large hand heavily ringed, a steady face, strong features, and great composure of manner. There was a character about Madame Defarge, from which one might have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings over which she presided. Madame Defarge being sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and had a quantity of bright shawl twined about her head,
en_second_half: though not to the concealment of her large earrings. Her knitting was before her, but she had laid it down to pick her teeth with a toothpick. Thus engaged, with her right elbow supported by her left hand, Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in, but coughed just one grain of cough. This, in combination with the lifting of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a line, suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the shop among the customers, for any new customer who had dropped in while he stepped over the way.
en_results: which added to her already formidable appearance, and gave her the air of a woman not to be trifled with. Her eyes, though watchful, were not unkind, and there was a certain quiet dignity about her, that commanded respect. She looked up from the work she was engaged in, as her husband entered, and their eyes met in a brief, but significant glance. And with that, Madame Defarge returned to her work, her hands
en_results_raw: which added to her already formidable appearance, and gave her the air of a woman not to be trifled with. Her eyes, though watchful, were not unkind, and there was a certain quiet dignity about her, that commanded respect. She looked up from the work she was engaged in, as her husband entered, and their eyes met in a brief, but significant glance. It was a glance that spoke volumes, and told of a deep and abiding understanding between them, a glance that said, without words, "I know all, and I am prepared." And with that, Madame Defarge returned to her work, her hands moving with a quiet deliberation, as if she were weaving a spell of protection around herself, and those she loved. The shop, with its dark, rich smells, and its rows of gleaming bottles, seemed to grow quieter, as if it too, were waiting, with bated breath, to see what the future held. And in the silence, the clock on the wall, ticked on, its steady heartbeat, a reminder that time was passing, and that the events that were unfolding, were doing so, with a relentless and unstoppable force.

es_results_raw: la quietud eran tan densos que parecían tener un peso propio, como si el aire mismo estuviera cargado de una expectación contenida. La casa, con sus ventanas cerradas y su puerta inmóvil, parecía contener un secreto que solo esperaba ser descubierto. El viento, que normalmente susurraba a través de las calles, parecía haberse detenido también, como si estuviera esperando a que algo sucediera. En ese ambiente de suspense, cualquier ruido hubiera sido como un trueno en un día de verano, rompiendo la tensión que se había ido acumulando. Pero el silencio persistía, envolviendo todo en una capa de misterio y expectación.

Jerry nhìn vợ mình và thấy rằng cô ấy có vẻ lo lắng, anh hỏi tiếp: "Anh có cảm giác là có chuyện gì đó, anh không biết là gì, nhưng anh cảm thấy không ổn." Vợ anh nhìn anh và nói: "Đúng, có một chuyện, nhưng anh không cần phải lo lắng, mọi thứ sẽ ổn." Jerry nhìn vợ mình và thấy rằng cô ấy có vẻ bí mật, anh hỏi tiếp: "Anh muốn biết, anh cần phải biết, vợ anh ơi." Vợ anh nhìn anh và nói: "Được, anh sẽ biết, nhưng anh phải hứa là sẽ không lo lắng." Jerry nhìn vợ mình và nói: "Anh hứa, anh sẽ không lo lắng, anh chỉ muốn biết sự thật." Vợ anh nhìn anh và bắt đầu kể cho anh nghe về một chuyện mà anh không thể tưởng tượng được.

en_first_half: Although the Doctor’s daughter had known nothing of the country of her birth, she appeared to have innately derived from it that ability to make much of little means, which is one of its most useful and most agreeable characteristics. Simple as the furniture was, it was set off by so many little adornments, of no value but for their taste and fancy, that its effect was delightful. The disposition of everything in the rooms,
en_second_half: from the largest object to the least; the arrangement of colours, the elegant variety and contrast obtained by thrift in trifles, by delicate hands, clear eyes, and good sense; were at once so pleasant in themselves, and so expressive of their originator, that, as Mr. Lorry stood looking about him, the very chairs and tables seemed to ask him, with something of that peculiar expression which he knew so well by this time, whether he approved?
en_results: was so well calculated to please the eye, that it was impossible to be in them without feeling a sense of comfort and repose. The walls, painted a pale blue, were adorned with a few choice engravings, and a couple of water-color drawings, which, though not masterpieces, were executed with taste and feeling. The floor was covered with a neat, though not costly, carpet, and the windows were hung with curtains of a pretty pattern, which, being made
en_results_raw: was so well calculated to please the eye, that it was impossible to be in them without feeling a sense of comfort and repose. The walls, painted a pale blue, were adorned with a few choice engravings, and a couple of water-color drawings, which, though not masterpieces, were executed with taste and feeling. The floor was covered with a neat, though not costly, carpet, and the windows were hung with curtains of a pretty pattern, which, being made of a light material, did not shut out the sun, but only softened its rays. The whole was so well arranged, that it seemed the result of a careful and well-studied plan, rather than the chance and careless selection of a few articles of furniture. The Doctor's daughter had, in short, shown a great deal of taste and ingenuity in the arrangement of her rooms, and had made the most of the means at her disposal.

Cô ta đã tạo nên một không gian sống mà ở đó, mọi thứ đều được sắp xếp một cách hợp lý và thẩm mỹ, tạo nên một cảm giác ấm cúng và thoải mái cho bất cứ ai bước vào. Đó là một không gian sống mà cô ta đã tạo nên bằng sự khéo léo và chăm sóc của mình, và nó phản ánh được tính cách và phong cách sống của cô ta.
es_first_half: Aunque nada aprendió la hija del doctor en su patria de origen, es lo cierto que ésta la inició en aquella habilidad rara que consiste en hacer mucho con medios escasos, lo que constituía una de sus características más preciosas y agradables. Modesto y sencillo era el mobiliario de las habitaciones de la casa, y esto no obstante, algunas chucherías, que no tenían más valor real que el gusto exquisito con que estaban colocadas, daban a aquéllas un efecto delicioso.
es_second_half: La disposición de cuanto en la casa había, comenzando por el mueble más grande y acabando por el objeto más insignificante, la combinación de colores, y el contraste obtenido merced a nonadas por manos delicadas, ojos de mirada clara y sentidos de gusto irreprochable, ofrecían un conjunto tan agradable en sí y retrataban tan gráficamente a su autora, que no parecía sino que con mudo pero elocuente lenguaje preguntaban al señor Lorry, mientras extasiado los contemplaba, si merecían su aprobación.
es_results: De la misma manera, la ropa de la hija del doctor, aunque no era de las más costosas, estaba siempre limpia y planchada, y su peinado, sencillo pero elegante, realzaba su rostro fresco y sonriente. La hija del doctor sabía sacar partido de todo, y su habilidad para hacer mucho con poco era verdaderamente admirable. Su madre, que había sido una mujer de gran belleza y elegancia en su juventud, le había enseñado el valor de la sencillez y la modestia, y la hija del doctor había aprendido bien la lección.
es_results_raw: De la misma manera, la ropa de la hija del doctor, aunque no era de las más costosas, estaba siempre limpia y planchada, y su peinado, sencillo pero elegante, realzaba su rostro fresco y sonriente. La hija del doctor sabía sacar partido de todo, y su habilidad para hacer mucho con poco era verdaderamente admirable. Su madre, que había sido una mujer de gran belleza y elegancia en su juventud, le había enseñado el valor de la sencillez y la modestia, y la hija del doctor había aprendido bien la lección. A pesar de que su padre era un hombre acomodado, la hija del doctor no había crecido con la idea de que el dinero era lo único que importaba en la vida, y su madre había visto con orgullo cómo su hija había desarrollado una personalidad propia, llena de bondad y generosidad. La hija del doctor era, en resumen, una joven con un gran corazón y una gran capacidad para hacer felices a los demás, y su presencia en la casa era un regalo para todos los que la conocían.

en_results_raw: She could always hear the soft cooing of her child, the gentle babbling of her little one, the sweet nothings that only a mother's ears are attuned to. And as she sat there, lost in the simple joys of motherhood, the world outside receded, its troubles and cares growing fainter with each passing moment. The advancing echoes of life, with all their attendant worries and fears, were muffled and indistinct, unable to penetrate the warm, golden glow that surrounded her and her child. In this peaceful, sheltered world, time itself seemed to stand still, and all that existed was the gentle rhythm of her child's breathing, the soft rise and fall of its tiny chest, the sweet, innocent beauty of its sleeping face.

El rumor hablaba de un ángel que había descendido del cielo para visitar a los muertos, y que se paseaba entre las tumbas, dejando un rastro de luz y esperanza en su camino. La gente del pueblo se reunía en el cementerio, ansiosa por escuchar el rumor y sentir la presencia del ángel. Algunos decían haber visto su figura blanca y resplandeciente, mientras que otros afirmaban haber escuchado su voz suave y consoladora. El rumor se extendió por todo el valle, y pronto la gente de los pueblos vecinos se unió a la multitud que se reunía en el cementerio. Todos esperaban con ansiedad la aparición del ángel, y muchos se preguntaban qué mensaje traería consigo. ¿Sería un mensaje de esperanza y redención, o acaso un aviso de peligro y destrucción? Solo el tiempo lo diría, pero una cosa era segura: el rumor del ángel había despertado algo en el corazón de la gente, algo que no podía ser ignorado.

I am astonished, sir, at your simplicity. I am astonished at the facility with which you are led away by the first pretender that chooses to impose upon your credulity. You are like a child, that is put into the hands of a conjurer, who shows him a few tricks, and the poor child believes all that the conjurer tells him. I am ashamed of you, Mr. Darnay, I am ashamed of your want of penetration, of your want of knowledge of the world. You are a man of sense, and yet you are so easily imposed upon. I am afraid, sir, that you will be the dupe of every impostor, that chooses to take you in hand. I am afraid, sir, that you will be the laughing stock of every one, that knows you. I am afraid, sir, that you will be the very jest of the town. And all this, sir, because you have not the sense to see through the artifices of a designing villain. I am sorry, sir, to see you in this situation. I am sorry, sir, to see you so far imposed upon. But I hope, sir, that you will soon see your error, and that you will soon be undeceived. I hope, sir, that you will soon discover the true character of this impostor, and that you will soon be ashamed of the part you have acted.

es_results_raw: de la juventud, fantasmas de la vida. Y él, Carlos Darnay, se sentía como un intruso, un ser vivo en un mundo de sombras. La atmósfera era tan opresiva que parecía que el aire mismo estaba cargado de tristeza. Los ojos de las personas allí reunidas parecían haber perdido su brillo, su chispa, y solo reflejaban una profunda desesperanza. Carlos Darnay se preguntaba cómo era posible que un lugar que en otro tiempo debió ser un símbolo de la alegría y la diversión, ahora fuera un reflejo de la miseria y la desesperación. ¿Qué había pasado para que todo cambiara de esa manera? ¿Qué había sucedido con la gente que una vez llenó esta sala de risas y música? ¿Dónde estaban ahora? ¿Habían desaparecido, como fantasmas, en la nada? Carlos Darnay no podía sacudirse de la cabeza esas preguntas, mientras observaba a los fantasmas que lo rodeaban, con sus rostros pálidos y sus ojos vacíos.

The wood-sawyer, who had been watching the scene with a look of curiosity, now turned to Lucie and asked her if she was alright, for she looked pale and shaken. Lucie, still trying to process what had just happened, nodded slowly and took a step back into the shop, her eyes fixed on the wood-sawyer's face as if searching for some sort of reassurance. The wood-sawyer, seeming to sense her unease, nodded sympathetically and gestured for her to sit down, saying that he would get her a glass of water. As Lucie sat down on a nearby stool, she couldn't help but wonder what had just happened, and what the Carmagnole's sudden appearance had meant.

The men, who had been drinking, were thrown into a state of the utmost confusion and terror, and, in their efforts to escape, they trampled each other, and many of them were severely injured. The fire, which had begun in the room, soon spread to the other parts of the house, and, in a short time, the whole building was in flames. The people of the neighborhood, who had been alarmed by the cries of those who were escaping from the house, hastened to the scene, and, with the assistance of the fire department, they were able to extinguish the flames, and prevent the fire from spreading to the adjoining houses. The loss of property was, however, very great, and many of the men who had been in the house were severely burned, and some of them died in consequence of their injuries.

en_results_raw: She was sitting on the same couch, in the same dress, with the same smile, and the same eyes that had haunted him for so long. He felt a sense of peace wash over him as he looked at her, and he knew that he was home. The dream, or whatever it was, had been so real, so vivid, that he had almost forgotten what it was like to be happy. But now, with Lucie by his side, he felt like he could finally breathe again. He reached out and took her hand, and she didn't pull away. Instead, she squeezed it gently, and he felt a spark of electricity run through his body. He looked into her eyes, and saw the same love and adoration that he had seen all those years ago. And in that moment, he knew that he was exactly where he was meant to be.

en_results: wrist now, and with that last word, he had turned her hand gently over. The blood rushed to her cheeks, and her eyes, cast down before, were lifted to his. "I should have used the opportunity,
en_results_raw: wrist now, and with that last word, he had turned her hand gently over. The blood rushed to her cheeks, and her eyes, cast down before, were lifted to his. "I should have used the opportunity, I should have used it, long and long ago." He had not loosed her hand, and she did not draw it away. "You would have been happier," he said. "You would have been happier, and I should have been happier. It might have been all so different." He looked at her, his eyes burning with the intensity of his feelings. "It might have been all so different," he repeated. "But it is not too late," he said, his voice low and full of emotion. "It is not too late, my dear. It is not too late for us." He drew her closer, his arm around her waist, and she did not resist. She felt the warmth of his body, the beat of his heart, and she knew that she was his, and that he was hers. They stood there, wrapped in each other's arms, the world around them fading away, leaving only the two of them, lost in their own little world of love and longing.
